Enumeration.name: LibLLVMValueKind
Enumeration.summary: Enum to match the underlying raw LLVM Value kind enumeration
Enumeration.remarks:
In order to map from an arbitrary LLVMValueRef to a wrapped managed type the exact kind of value must be known. However, the LLVM-C API uses a value kind that is not complete and doesn't match the underlying enum values. (It includes complex transforms to ensure the 'C' API is "stable". This, causes problems for managed projections like Llvm.NET. So as an extension to LLVM-C the LibLLVM library supports a method to get at the underlying value.
It is important to note that the enumerated values here are subject to change with every version of LLVM. Generally, this is only intended for use within the object model projection of Llvm.NET.

Delegate.name: LibLLVMValueCacheItemDeletedCallback
Delegate.summary: Native call back for when an item in the value cache is deleted
Delegate.param: LLVM handle for the value being removed
App provided opaque handle for the app managed item

Delegate.name: LibLLVMValueCacheItemReplacedCallback
Delegate.summary: Callback for when a value in the cache is replaced
Delegate.param: Original LLVM value handle for the value being replaced
App provided opaque handle for the value
LLVM handle for the replacement value
Delegate.returns: App defined opaque handle for the new value

Function.name: LibLLVMIsConstantZeroValue
Function.summary: Tests if a value is the constant zero form of the value
Function.param: Value to test
Function.returns: if the value is the constant 0

Function.name: LibLLVMRemoveGlobalFromParent
Function.summary: Removes a global from the containing module
Function.param: Global to remove from it's parent

Function.name: LibLLVMGetValueID
Function.summary: Gets an ID for the concrete type of this object.
Function.param: Value to get the ID from
Function.remarks: This is used to implement the classof checks that enable interop code to determine the correct derived type for a generic . This should not be used for any other purpose, as the values do change as LLVM evolves. Also, note that for instructions, the Instruction's opcode is added to InstructionVal.
